notes: Strictly limit phenylalanine intake; use medical formula for protein.

Same dietary restrictions as Type I; ensure metabolic balance and monitor neurologic signs.

Restrict intake of odd-chain amino acids (isoleucine, valine, methionine, threonine); avoid high-protein foods.
Avoid precursors of propionyl-CoA; restrict animal proteins; use medical formula for nutrition.
Restrict lysine and tryptophan; avoid high-protein foods such as meat and eggs.

diseaseName: Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (Von Gierke Disease)
notes: Avoid fructose, lactose, galactose; maintain frequent cornstarch feedings to prevent hypoglycemia.

diseaseName: Glycogen Storage Disease Type III (Cori Disease)
notes: High-protein, complex carbohydrate diet; frequent feedings to maintain normoglycemia.

diseaseName: Glycogen Storage Disease Type V (McArdle Disease)
notes: Moderate protein; pre-exercise carbohydrate loading; avoid prolonged anaerobic exertion.
Avoid fasting, sucrose, fructose, and glycerol; maintain glucose intake regularly.
Absolutely avoid fructose, sucrose, sorbitol, and honey; use glucose-based carbs only.
Avoid fava beans, menthol, artificial dyes, and oxidative stress-inducing foods or drugs.
Strictly avoid all milk and dairy products; restrict galactose and lactose; calcium supplementation required.

Avoid long-chain fatty acids; frequent carbohydrate feedings; use MCT oil.

Avoid fasting; low-leucine, low-fat diet; ensure glucose availability.
Low-fat, high-carb diet; avoid fasting and strenuous exercise; riboflavin supplement needed.

diseaseName: Glucose Transporter Type 1 Deficiency Syndrome (GLUT1 DS)
notes: Strict ketogenic diet essential; minimize carbohydrate intake to support brain energy.
No specific dietary restrictions; lifelong biotin supplementation required.
Avoid fasting; protein moderation may be needed; maintain stable glucose and biotin supplementation.
Severe intolerance to protein-rich foods; restrict animal proteins; supplement citrulline and protein-free amino acids.

Adequate protein allowed; supplement creatine, arginine, or glycine depending on subtype.
No specific dietary restrictions; copper-histidine supplementation is the primary therapy.
Avoid high-copper foods (e.g., shellfish, nuts, chocolate); maintain low-copper diet and chelation therapy.
Avoid iron-rich foods (e.g., red meat, iron-fortified cereals); avoid vitamin C supplements with iron.
Follow a low-saturated-fat, low-cholesterol diet; avoid trans fats and fried foods.
Supplement cholesterol; moderate fat and protein intake; avoid fasting and ensure consistent energy supply.
